And Ross, where is your "god" during all of the long list of atrocities you cite? Where was god during Stalin's slaughter, where was god when thousands of priests abused little boys?  You complain about the weakness of atheism, how about the absolute lack of proof of a god?

But John, you DO know God! There is not a human being that does not know God, at one level or another. Why, even the atheistic secularist knows God. The problem is that he practices self-deception, just as man has been doing for millenia.

Here is how the Bible states this universal fact:

"The wrath of God is being revealed from heaven against all ungodliness and wickedness of men *who suppress* [self-deceive] the truth by their wickedness, since what may be known of God *is PLAIN* to them, because God has made it plain to them. For since the creation of the world God's invisible qualities -his eternal power and divine nature - have been CLEARLY SEEN, being understood by what is made, so that men are without excuse."

Bottom line: there is no such thing as an true atheist. To be one, that person would have to renounce his humanity altogether. This he cannot do without going insane. That is the iceberg-like intellectual crisis that unbelieving man cannot face.

Proposing this may be pointless, since I've done it before, but nevertheless I will again: an argument about God using language that incorporates cultural and traditional history the language takes for granted is pointless.

To frankly address atheism in the context of what humanity has learned since God was proposed, and in which environment the God-concept evolved, it becomes necessary to discard those concepts, i.e., that language.

If I say that I don't believe in God, Ross, I mean quite frankly that insofar as no human being "knows" God, then God is a theory used to underwrite the anxiety life creates; in that case any God is as legitimate as another.

God is a word, a name. If someone calls my name they know relatively precisely what the name represents. But in sharing the name God world religions do not.

Science and theology wouldn't be confrontational except that religion insists on sole ownership of existential mystery. Science agrees that the universe is incredibly complex; indecipherably complex for now. But religion insists on limiting that complexity by drawing a border around it that each religion insists on controlling by insisting its adherents "believe" in an undefinable God that each religion nevertheless reserves the right to define.

No thanks. I don't, can't, believe any of that any longer. Read J B Phillips "Your God Is Too small" Ross. It will do you, and us, much good and may quiet your incessant anxiety that insists in your proselytizing us.

That's a pretty gross generalization about teachers.

I have observed hundreds of classrooms for decades with remarkable teachers. They are dedicated and hard working. Many spend hours evenings and weekends preparing lessons and grading far too many papers from overcrowded classrooms. They do not resist change - they embrace it - they write challenging goals for themselves - attend workshops - (not just to learn jargon) - teach each other - and remain current.

And, they also embrace quality evaluation processes - the kind where they get constructive feedback from a colleague or administrator and self-reflection. Some of the new systems are demeaning trying to turn teaching into a score based on single tests but the observations, reviews of artifacts and lessons, and review of student work is valued and valuable. Sure there are a few that have lost their way or don't dig in as deeply as others but the vast majority are professionals doing professional work with every child no matter what their zip code, nationality, disability, or motivation.

The common core standards are being debated as article notes mostly on the periphery of who wrote them and paid for them and the overuse of testing - teachers are working hard at making challenging standards work, revising where possible, aligning curriculum that works for their kids, and not narrowing curriculum to pass tests.

The US Constitution also expressly provides (Article 2, Section2, Clause 1) that: "The President shall be Commander in Chief of the Army and Navy of the United States, and of the Militia of the several States, when called into the actual Service of the United States..." In that capacity, the President is responsible and answerable to the American people for the defense of the United States against military attack, or armed insurrection.

There is no exception from that duty when the adversaries mounting the attacks happen to be irregular forces not identified with a national government. Nobody, for example, questions the power of the President, through the US Navy, to defend shipping against attacks by pirates, even though pirates are not considered to be the military forces of a foreign national government.

What specific provision and language in the Constitution do you consider to override Article 2, Section 2, Section 1?

When irregular armed forces not associated with a nation-state destroyed both the towers of the World Trade Center on 9/11, and killed all the civilians remaining in them when they collapsed, and US Air Force fighters appeared in the sky over Manhattan, nobody asked whether Congress had declared war, or whether any members of the attacking forces were American citizens. Would the President, and the US Air Force, have been powerless to act if an additional hijacked plane had shown up that day and tried to attack the Empire State Building?

Karen,

Thanks for what you wrote.

I also feel as if I have gotten treated as a widow as if I lost my intelligence along with my husband -- as if widowhood makes one stupid.

For 26 years until retiring in 2008, I was a Social Worker in Washington State for the Dept of Children & Family Services.
Many of the children/teens I served had severe behavioral and emotional problems to the extent that they could not live appropriately or safely in the community, and were in residential treatment programs. It goes without saying that they came from unstable backgrounds.
In all those years, I never met one damaged child placed in a group home who, from his/her birth, had a dedicated, loving, present, sober, and stable father. Not one.

Powerful start, wonderful writing.

True, some fathers don't know. My father's father was killed in a train accident when my father was too young to remember him, and his mother raised him alone. He was troubled about being a father, and talked about that. He did very well anyway, because he tried. That is what it takes, more than anything else.

One of my sons has the impulse control issues mentioned by Mr. Blow. We work on that. I tell him of my issues with that, of my father's issues with that, and that a "real man" must get a grip on it. I try to be an example, and if I mess up, I admit it and use THAT as an example. We are making progress, despite my own issues with it.

My other son has issues with paying attention is school. That took firmness, but more than that it took example. It was important to me. I had overcome the temptations, and he could do what I did. I presented it as example of my own efforts, not just the boot in rear (but that too).

For my father and for me, it is not necessary to know how, or to be perfect on these things ourselves. We just have to be there and care and try.

My sons are doing fine, and I am proud of them. It was work. I'm sure it will be more. But that is its own reward too.
